title: De Witt (family)
text:
De Witt (also: De Wit, De Witte and De With) is the name of an old Dutch <a href="Patrician%20%28post-Roman%20Europe%29">patrician</a> and <a href="regenten">regenten</a> family. Originally from <a href="Dordrecht">Dordrecht</a>, the genealogy of the family begins with Jan de Witte, a patrician who lived around 1295. The family have played an important role during the <a href="Dutch%20Golden%20Age">Dutch Golden Age</a>. They were at the centre of Dordrecht and <a href="Holland">Holland</a> oligarchy from the end of the 16th century until 1672, and belonged to the <a href="Dutch%20States%20Party">Dutch States Party</a>. 
The De Witt family during the Dutch Golden Age.
During the <a href="Dutch%20Golden%20Age">Dutch Golden Age</a>, the <a href="Republicanism">republican</a> de Witt family opposed the <a href="royalists">royalists</a> associated with the <a href="House%20of%20Orange-Nassau">House of Orange-Nassau</a>. With other republican political leaders at Dordrecht, such as the van Slingelandts, and at Amsterdam with the <a href="Bicker%20family">Bicker</a> and <a href="de%20Graeff">de Graeff</a> families, the de Witts worked to abolish <a href="stadtholder">stadtholder</a>ship. They sought full sovereignty for individual regions, so that the <a href="Dutch%20Republic">Republic of the United Seven Netherlands</a> would not yield to authoritarianism. Instead of a sovereigns (or stadtholder), political and military power would be entrusted to the States General and Holland's city <a href="regent">regent</a>s.
From 1650 into the 1670s, the de Witts played leading roles in Dutch government. Republicans called this era the "Ware Vrijheid" (True Freedom), the <a href="First%20Stadtholderless%20Period">First Stadtholderless Period</a>.
The de Witt family lost its leadership role in <a href="Rampjaar">Rampjaar</a> 1672, when <a href="Orangism%20%28Netherlands%29">Orangists</a> resumed leadership and murdered brothers <a href="Johan%20de%20Witt">Johan</a> and <a href="Cornelis%20de%20Witt">Cornelis de Witt</a>.
